Ensure access to sustainable & clean water and sanitation for all. 7. Ensure access to affordable, clean and modern energy for all. 8. Promote sustainable economic growth, full employment, and decent work. 9. Build resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization, and foster innovation. 10. Reduce inequality within and among countries. 11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable 12. Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns. 13. Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts. 14. Conserve and sustainably use water bodies - oceans, seas, and marine resources. 15. Protect, restore, and sustainably use terrestrial ecosystems and preserve biodiversity. 16. Promote peaceful and inclusive societies, ensure access to justice, and build effective institutions. 17. Strengthen global partnerships for sustainable development. questions.question: Main focus of UNICEF is on
questions.explanation: child health. UNICEF is an international organization that works specifically for the well-being and rights of children worldwide. It operates in various areas related to child health, including healthcare, nutrition, immunization, access to clean water and sanitation, education, protection from exploitation and violence, and emergency response in times of crises. Incorrect Options Option A: Social health- While UNICEF does address social determinants of health that can affect child well-being, its main focus is broader than just social health. Option B: Mental health- UNICEF's focus extends beyond mental health to address other areas of child health and development. Option C: Nutritional health- Nutritional health is not the sole focus but rather one aspect of its broader mandate to promote the overall health and well-being of children.

questions.question: What is the origin of the Sustainable Development Goals?
questions.explanation: the United Nations (UN). The SDGs are a set of global goals adopted by UN member states in 2015 as part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. These goals aim to address various social, economic, and environmental challenges faced by countries around the world. Incorrect Options Option A: UNICEF- While UNICEF is a part of the United Nations system it is not solely responsible for designing the Sustainable Development Goals. Option C: WHO- . While WHO contributes to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, it is not solely responsible for designing them. Option D: Government of India- The Government of India is not responsible for designing the Sustainable Development Goals.

questions.question: Kyoto Protocol is for
questions.explanation: that was adopted in Kyoto, Japan, in 1997 under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Its main objective is to combat climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The protocol sets binding targets for industrialized countries to reduce their emissions of six greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide, over specific commitment periods. Incorrect Options Option A:To improve water sanitization- The Kyoto Protocol does not specifically focus on water sanitization. Option B: To study food and nutrition- The Kyoto Protocol is not related to the study of food and nutrition. Option D: To do water chlorination- The Kyoto Protocol does not deal with water chlorination.

questions.question: What immunization coverage percentage is required by the WHO for the eradication of measles?
questions.explanation: immunization coverage is needed for the eradication of measles. Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that can spread rapidly among unvaccinated populations. Achieving a high level of immunization coverage is crucial to control and eliminate measles. The 96% immunization coverage target is set to ensure that a significant proportion of the population is protected against the measles virus, creating herd immunity. Incorrect Options: Option A- 68%: This percentage is too low to achieve herd immunity and effectively control the spread of measles. Option B- 72%: Similar to option A, this percentage is insufficient to achieve the desired level of immunization coverage for measles eradication. Option C- 84%: While this percentage is higher than the previous options, it still falls short of the recommended 96% coverage needed for measles eradication.
